attanments. It is to be DAILY MORNING PAPER, ,de- voted principally to cOmmere and manufactures but including politics, literature, and whatever else that may be Interesting to intelligent men of business Ad- vertisments for the theatre, of lottery tickets, and of business to be transacted the Sabbath, will be cuded. It is intended that the Skipping List shall be surpassed in the country, especially will more thorough attention be paid to Eastern vessels than IS usual in New-York. A price current will be inserted as soon as arrangements can be made furnish one, which can be relied upon. The price is the same as other New-York papers, $10.-A Journal will be s- sued SEM1-WEEKLY, containing the principal matter, at $4. To companies subscribing six papers seventh will be included gratis.

 The gentlemen who have determined upon the es- tablishmen of this paper have not done it with view to any pecuniary advantage. They have higher motive and which has long interested the feelings of moral and religious men in Boston, New York and other cities. They ready to sacrifice money, to any amount which may be required. But 1t is evi- dent that to accomplish any valuable purpose wide circulation must be had. good subscription list has been obtained in NewYork but the enterprise is in its character and has to contend with many and powerful obstacles. To overcome these, no labor expense the part of the projectors or the Ed tors will be spared. And they invite the hearty CO., operation of all those who would sustain the business of the country and it's civil and literary institutions upon the basis of Christian religion and sound nor ality.

 The publication will be commenced as soon the details of preparation be arranged. And it is re- quested that should be returned soon, without the payment of postage, to Arther Tappan Esq. New York. DAVID HALE.

 Whea Crcps.-From Virginia and Maryland we hear that seasOnable rains had improved the Wheat crops in those states, and that there was prosDect of an abundant harvest. The alarm caused by the rayages Ofthe Hessian fly had in good degree sub sided.

 The three SpanIards concerned in the murder of the crew of the brig Crawford, have been examined at Norfolk. The examination developed scenes of the most cold blOOded cruelty. Their names are FeLer, COuVTO and Pope. The former is about 5 years of age, the two latter not old. Pope is supposed to be the most hardened villain of the three, he hay ing boasted to Mr. Guiouhiac that ''he had the hon. or of Killing Capt. Brighman and the IrishmaD with his own hands," They will probably be tried before the Circuit Court of the United States in session at Richmond.

 GOSHEN, N. Y. July 2.

 Destructive HGI StOrm.--The north west part of our county has been visited by most extraordinary and destructive hail storm, de- strOyiDg in it's course acres of most beautiful grain. On Monday afternoon last, there was violent shower, accompanied with hail, com menced in the north part of the town of Cal hOun, passed across the town of Minisink to BroOkhRId, and from thence extending through the Drowned Lands to Pine Island and Amity, in the town of Warwick, fields of grain were completely destroyed, Some far mers lost all they had sown; scarcely spear left standing. We have heard that sev- eral individuals estimate their losses at $500.

 The size of the hail stones were unusually large. averaging from three quarters to one inch in diameter. Many pains of glass were broken. In the Brookfield Meeting House, something like l5O were destroyed, and in Amity Meeting House still larger number. It made great havoc among the poultry, ,and we are told that even calves were much in- jured. On the day after the storm, large quantities of the hail stones were collected in places, bushels were scraped together and deposited in ice houses.

 Thus were blasted in few short minutes, the well-founded hopes of many of our far mers, who to all appearance seemed justified in anticipating abundant crops; but at the same time. we are all practically taught val able lesson, upon the uncertainty of things in this lifn.-Ind. Rep.

The work is so generally known to all who are acquainted with the publications of the present day. that it is deemed unnecessary to enlarge upon it's contents"

"THE SOUVENIR" will be published every We'd nesday morning. extra-medium fine white paper printed with new and elegant type and decorated in addition to the engravngs alluded above with ma ny appropriate embellishments. Each No. will com prise eight pages cut, stched and expressly adanted for binding. At the expiration of every year. or at the close of volume, subscribers will be furnished gratis with general index of the contents, and a handsomely engraved tltle-page.

 Price of subscription $2 50 per annum payable in advance. Postmaters and others out of the city, pro- curing five subscribers and becoming responsible for the payment, will be entitled sixth copy gratis.

 The Copperplate embellishments will be superinten. ded by the Publisher and the typographical part of this work will be under the exlusive directions of Messrs. Atkinson & Alexander who have long been known to the public able and enterprsng artizans that IS entirely unnecessary to say that far they are concerned there be doubt sto the elegance of its execution; and with regard to his own share of the arrangemens the Publisher binds himself case he should fail to perform any essential part of his un- dertaking to refund tie price of subscription.

 Agents will shortly be appointed in di iferent parts of the United Statfs, until which time subscriptions wlI be received by PHILIP PRICE, Jr. Mo- 6S Lombard street, Philadelphia whom all orders must he ad dressed, post paid-And also by JUDAH DORSON. 1OS Chesnut street; at the Office of the SATURDAY. FROM cLERGYMEN OF VARIOUS DENOMINATIONS. From the Rec. Dr. Gri6in.--"I esteem Dr. Scott's Family Bible, eminenty calculated to promote the cause of truth and piety 1t seems scarcely possible for me to read daily the Notes and Observations with out becoming wiser and better man."

 Rep Asa Eaton, pastor ot' Christ Chasrch, Boston. -" It is a TREASURE WHICH EVERY FAMILY OUGHT TO POSSESS For the success of your undertaking you have my best wishes and fervent prayers" E

 Rev Dr. Jeshua Bates, President Of Msddleb,uy publishing Scott's Family Bible, and sincerely wish you success in your undertaking. have doubt that it will be well patronzed by the religious public"

 Rep Danisl Sharp, pastor cf tue Sd Bapsist Charch, on The more it is read by pious Christians, the more extensive will be its circulation" &sG .3 Church, Boston.-"I feel free to say that in my esti nation it deseryedy ranks among our abest and best Commentaries. All the leading doctrines ot Chris tianity as professed and maintained by many ot the eminent Reformers, are in my judgment very hap oily illustrated and enforced"

 Rev Dr. Dana.-" Dr. Scott's Commentary, has merited and obtained distinguished popularity The spirit which pervaes the work is excellent. 1t is the meek, aectonate, healing yet faithful spirit of the Gospel.

 entiat a'osg the Clergy hdUe reco"needed ths soork; the toosciRg ertracts, hoaCeUer, from Mr Emnersos letter suiA pOiat out the adrantages peculiar to the OC TAVO eaition.

 Rep Joseph Emerson, Author of tue Eramgslical Prinser-' Six editions of this great work have been published in this county.-I have had considerable opportunity to examine and compare specimens of all these six editions and decidedly of opinion, that most people would greatly prefer ARMSTRONG'S EDITION, now publishing in Boston. As the fold is octave, he volumes are not nearly so large as the quarto editons but the paper finer and whiter the execution handsomer the print to appearance nearly as large; and it can be turned to the light with much less Inconvenience, it may perhaps he read with equal ease and pleasure. It has the advantage of be- ing cheaper, less cumbersome, and more elegant.

 "ARMSTRONG'S EDITION, therefore, is the one which can most highly recommend for the use of families. It is peculiarly calculated to supersede the use of large Bible and in two respects it will answer better purpose merely for reading the scrip lures, as 1t is less cumbersome, and may be read by several persons at the same time."

full articles.article:
attanments. It is to be DAILY MORNING PAPER, ,de- voted principally to cOmmere and manufactures but including politics, literature, and whatever else that may be Interesting to intelligent men of business Ad- vertisments for the theatre, of lottery tickets, and of business to be transacted the Sabbath, will be cuded. It is intended that the Skipping List shall be surpassed in the country, especially will more thorough attention be paid to Eastern vessels than IS usual in New-York. A price current will be inserted as soon as arrangements can be made furnish one, which can be relied upon. The price is the same as other New-York papers, $10.-A Journal will be s- sued SEM1-WEEKLY, containing the principal matter, at $4. To companies subscribing six papers seventh will be included gratis.

 The gentlemen who have determined upon the es- tablishmen of this paper have not done it with view to any pecuniary advantage. They have higher motive and which has long interested the feelings of moral and religious men in Boston, New York and other cities. They ready to sacrifice money, to any amount which may be required. But 1t is evi- dent that to accomplish any valuable purpose wide circulation must be had. good subscription list has been obtained in NewYork but the enterprise is in its character and has to contend with many and powerful obstacles. To overcome these, no labor expense the part of the projectors or the Ed tors will be spared. And they invite the hearty CO., operation of all those who would sustain the business of the country and it's civil and literary institutions upon the basis of Christian religion and sound nor ality.

 The publication will be commenced as soon the details of preparation be arranged. And it is re- quested that should be returned soon, without the payment of postage, to Arther Tappan Esq. New York. DAVID HALE.

dangerous and extensive iBsnrrectiOn Of tbe blacks hes been timely detected and defeated, Ma con, n Georgia. letter states that they head. ed by French emigrani, from the Mississippi who, with the other leaders in the plot has escaped the of justice.

 Whea Crcps.-From Virginia and Maryland we hear that seasOnable rains had improved the Wheat crops in those states, and that there was prosDect of an abundant harvest. The alarm caused by the rayages Ofthe Hessian fly had in good degree sub sided.

 The three SpanIards concerned in the murder of the crew of the brig Crawford, have been examined at Norfolk. The examination developed scenes of the most cold blOOded cruelty. Their names are FeLer, COuVTO and Pope. The former is about 5 years of age, the two latter not old. Pope is supposed to be the most hardened villain of the three, he hay ing boasted to Mr. Guiouhiac that ''he had the hon. or of Killing Capt. Brighman and the IrishmaD with his own hands," They will probably be tried before the Circuit Court of the United States in session at Richmond.

 GOSHEN, N. Y. July 2.

 Destructive HGI StOrm.--The north west part of our county has been visited by most extraordinary and destructive hail storm, de- strOyiDg in it's course acres of most beautiful grain. On Monday afternoon last, there was violent shower, accompanied with hail, com menced in the north part of the town of Cal hOun, passed across the town of Minisink to BroOkhRId, and from thence extending through the Drowned Lands to Pine Island and Amity, in the town of Warwick, fields of grain were completely destroyed, Some far mers lost all they had sown; scarcely spear left standing. We have heard that sev- eral individuals estimate their losses at $500.

 The size of the hail stones were unusually large. averaging from three quarters to one inch in diameter. Many pains of glass were broken. In the Brookfield Meeting House, something like l5O were destroyed, and in Amity Meeting House still larger number. It made great havoc among the poultry, ,and we are told that even calves were much in- jured. On the day after the storm, large quantities of the hail stones were collected in places, bushels were scraped together and deposited in ice houses.

 Thus were blasted in few short minutes, the well-founded hopes of many of our far mers, who to all appearance seemed justified in anticipating abundant crops; but at the same time. we are all practically taught val able lesson, upon the uncertainty of things in this lifn.-Ind. Rep.

 "In sheep binding, the price is $24; and in cali binding $3O; from which prices very liberal DIS COUNT is made to agents and others who buy to sell again. The work IS comprised in six volumes, royal octavo and well bound and lettered, it will be sold cheap in proportion to the size of the pages, as the publications of the American Tract Society sold.

 EVERY FOURTH SET GRATIS! That is any person who takes three sets in sheep binding and pays for them the sum of $72, shall be entitled to set gratis; or if the same sum of $72 is divided equally all the four sets it will reduce the amount payable for each of the four sets to $8 instead of24 being discount of 25 per from the retail price. discount IS made in the some propor- ton on calf binding and on ANY NUMBER OF COPIES, aboue four, ho'Ceuer iarge."

 p The price at the LITCHFIELD BOOK STORE is $21 per single set, and SIS per set where four or more are taken in company.

 "The work contains the Old and New Testaments, with copious Marginal References also valuable Notes explanatory of the Scrpures and iasty the Practi- cal Observations. The work is so generally known to all who are acquainted with the publications of the present day. that it is deemed unnecessary to enlarge upon it's contents"

 The first edition of this york; lthe constant and in- creasng sale of which proves the high esteem in which it is deservedy hed begun in l788 and published in London, in numbers consisted of 900 copies; the second in 18O5 of2 600; the third in 181O of2 0OO the fourth in 1812 O00 and the new edition is stee- otype the largest work submitted to that process Besides these eight other editions consisting, alto gether, of 25,25O copes were printed in the United States of America, from 1903 to 18l9."-Phiadeiphio Recorder. The June No. of "The Casket," which is pubish- ed monthly at this ofice contains view of the COT particular description of that celebrated scene beau tfuly illustrated in Walter Scott's novel of :. The Heart of Midlothian" Also ayiew of QUEBECK, taken from the Chandere, at sun-setting, with ap- propsiate narrative of ats romantic and picturesque scenery copied from Silliman's Tour. Nos. %, 2l 22 and g of "the School of Flora" and an original song, from the pen of our admired correspondent "SELHM," set to the music. The contents of this number abound with original Tales, Essays and Po- etry diversified by anecdote and useful miscellany

 Enlarged and improved as "the Casket' has recent y been it now presents the lovers oflteraure one of the chcapest compeDdiums of Miscellany to be found in the United 6atesi the engEavings three ac eompanying each No1 are in themselyes worthy of particular attention, end will form collection at the end of the year of upwards of thysx, superceeding in value the amount of the subscription: We do not hesitate tO say that the appearance and character of this work win continue to afford the most ample and The price of subscription is $2.5O in advance. The vou to consist of nearly five hundred pages large Lst Of Me Porratiss ad Vices already phbiishsd i. s# ths Nos. for this gear.

 John Adams late President of the United States John c. Calhoun, present Vice President of the Uni ted States; Robert Fulton. full articles.article:
"THE SOUVENIR" will be published every We'd nesday morning. extra-medium fine white paper printed with new and elegant type and decorated in addition to the engravngs alluded above with ma ny appropriate embellishments. Each No. will com prise eight pages cut, stched and expressly adanted for binding. At the expiration of every year. or at the close of volume, subscribers will be furnished gratis with general index of the contents, and a handsomely engraved tltle-page.

 Price of subscription $2 50 per annum payable in advance. Postmaters and others out of the city, pro- curing five subscribers and becoming responsible for the payment, will be entitled sixth copy gratis.

 The Copperplate embellishments will be superinten. ded by the Publisher and the typographical part of this work will be under the exlusive directions of Messrs. Atkinson & Alexander who have long been known to the public able and enterprsng artizans that IS entirely unnecessary to say that far they are concerned there be doubt sto the elegance of its execution; and with regard to his own share of the arrangemens the Publisher binds himself case he should fail to perform any essential part of his un- dertaking to refund tie price of subscription.

 Agents will shortly be appointed in di iferent parts of the United Statfs, until which time subscriptions wlI be received by PHILIP PRICE, Jr. Mo- 6S Lombard street, Philadelphia whom all orders must he ad dressed, post paid-And also by JUDAH DORSON. 1OS Chesnut street; at the Office of the SATURDAY. EVENING POST, Mo- ll2 Chesnut street, two doors below the Post-Ofhce.

 Post Masters, or other gentlemen, ordering six cop ics of the work. will receive one copy gratis.

full articles.article:
FROM cLERGYMEN OF VARIOUS DENOMINATIONS. From the Rec. Dr. Gri6in.--"I esteem Dr. Scott's Family Bible, eminenty calculated to promote the cause of truth and piety 1t seems scarcely possible for me to read daily the Notes and Observations with out becoming wiser and better man."

 Rep Asa Eaton, pastor ot' Christ Chasrch, Boston. -" It is a TREASURE WHICH EVERY FAMILY OUGHT TO POSSESS For the success of your undertaking you have my best wishes and fervent prayers" E

 Rev Dr. Jeshua Bates, President Of Msddleb,uy publishing Scott's Family Bible, and sincerely wish you success in your undertaking. have doubt that it will be well patronzed by the religious public"

 Rep Danisl Sharp, pastor cf tue Sd Bapsist Charch, on The more it is read by pious Christians, the more extensive will be its circulation" &sG .3 Church, Boston.-"I feel free to say that in my esti nation it deseryedy ranks among our abest and best Commentaries. All the leading doctrines ot Chris tianity as professed and maintained by many ot the eminent Reformers, are in my judgment very hap oily illustrated and enforced"

 Rev Dr. Dana.-" Dr. Scott's Commentary, has merited and obtained distinguished popularity The spirit which pervaes the work is excellent. 1t is the meek, aectonate, healing yet faithful spirit of the Gospel.

 entiat a'osg the Clergy hdUe reco"needed ths soork; the toosciRg ertracts, hoaCeUer, from Mr Emnersos letter suiA pOiat out the adrantages peculiar to the OC TAVO eaition.

 Rep Joseph Emerson, Author of tue Eramgslical Prinser-' Six editions of this great work have been published in this county.-I have had considerable opportunity to examine and compare specimens of all these six editions and decidedly of opinion, that most people would greatly prefer ARMSTRONG'S EDITION, now publishing in Boston. As the fold is octave, he volumes are not nearly so large as the quarto editons but the paper finer and whiter the execution handsomer the print to appearance nearly as large; and it can be turned to the light with much less Inconvenience, it may perhaps he read with equal ease and pleasure. It has the advantage of be- ing cheaper, less cumbersome, and more elegant.

 "ARMSTRONG'S EDITION, therefore, is the one which can most highly recommend for the use of families. It is peculiarly calculated to supersede the use of large Bible and in two respects it will answer better purpose merely for reading the scrip lures, as 1t is less cumbersome, and may be read by several persons at the same time."

 .r ALSO

At Court of Probate holden at Litch6eld, within and tor the District of Litchfeld, July 2d, 1927.

 PresentF. wOLCOTT, Esq. Judge. U fON the petition of William c. Abernethy and Elaha Smith, Guardians OfSOphia D. HOady and Lu- thcr Hoadly, minors, of HarwintOn in said District, showing to this Court that said Minors the inter- est hereinafter mentioned, in the following described real esate situate in the of Winchester, the n- terest of said Minors the whole ofsad property being subject to the incumbrance of the life esnte of their mother, Sophia Aber,ethy, (late Sophia Hoadly) in the one undivided third part thereof, viE:

 About three fourths of an ofland lying on the East Branch ofSiill River, about half mile north of Winsted Meeting House, in said of Winchester, with dwelling house and shed standing thereon.

 Aso sxty-scVen rods of land lying east ofthe piece above described.

 Also, the one undivided half of seven acres of land owned in common with Riley Whiting, lying on the East branch of said Still Rver and north of the high way leading to Wallng's hill.

 Also, one undivided half of Grist Mill and the undivided half of seven eights of the mill privilege, and the one undivided half of small mill house, with about one half of an of land which said mill and mill house stand.

 Also the one half of Clock Shop and the one half of seven eghts of the water privilege ofthe sae with the one half of small piece of land on which said shop stands, and that which adjoins the same which has heretofore been occupied as lumber yard.

 Also, the undivided third part of fifteen acres of land lying in said Winchester, the East Bank of said Still River, bounded north Halsey Burr and Riley Whiting :-praying for liberty to sell the same, as her petition on file, dated May 4, 1927.

 Whereupon this Court doth order that said petition be continued to the second Monday in September next at ten o'clock A. M then to be heard before this Court at the Probate Office in Ltchfeld in sad Dis. tric and that notice of the pendancy of said petition be given by publishing this order in newspaper prin" ted in said Ltch6ed three weeks successvey,a at least six weeks before said second Monday in September next. A Atrue Copy of Record.

 FREDERICK WOLCOTT, Judge.

PROPOSALS

 Bx F. PRICE, JR. No. oo LOMBARD STREET-PHILADELPH1A For publishing Literary Journal, to be called . THE SOUVENIR.

 ESTABLISHED WITH Splendid Qu0TtO Enp1nr99ars
full articles.article:
VTNHlS work is intended as an agreeable and inc

 s!fuctve compamon for the parlour, and an ap- proprate attendant the Toile-to be issued every Wednesday, commencing with the first "Wednesday in July next

 No exertIon will be spared to render THE SOUL yENIK Tn all respects worthy the patronage of the public, both as cheap and elegant emporium of use- ful and interesting information, and valuable repos- tory o choice specimens of Miscellaneous iterature- Strict attention will be bestowed the moral tenden- cy of 1.-THE SOUVENIR and a constant watch fitness preserved over the interests of virtue.

 portion of the contents will be as folows:-

 l. TALES, original and selected; EssAYs moral humorous, and scientific; POETRY original and selec- ted from the best American and Foreign publications BIOGRAPHICAL SKETCHES of distinguished persons, male and JemaIe particularly the latter: ANECDOTES BoN MoTs, SEc. &c. The original matter necessary for this department of paper will be furnished by individuals Who are advantageousy known to the pub lie through the medium of their Literary productions besides the numerous correspondents who may be cx- pected to contribute.

 II. MIscELLANY.-Interesting items of inteIh- gence, foreign and domestic occurrences deatfsmar rages, &c.

 HI. ENGRAvINGs.-The first number of every month will be embellished with splendid quarto Cop- perpLate EagrGUine fitted to the size of the work a. mong which will be the following -

 f, Aihambra, Ancient Palace of the Moorish Kings in Spain.

 kill.

 Etna, from the Gardens of the Prince of Biscaria,

 View of St. Petersburgh.

 Arch Street Ferry; Philadelphia.

 Paraclete, founded by Abelard. ..... ..

 Giants Causeway and Bridge of fBridon.

 State Prison at Auburn, New-York. Tynwad Hill Isle of Man.

 Burning Fountain, one of the seven wonders ot Dauphiny. "a.

 Grotto of Osellas.

 Temple of Pluto.

 Pont Du Gard, near Nismes, Languedoc

 Saussure's Ascent of Mont Blanc.

 Cascade near Oysans, Dauphiny.

 Desert of the Grand Chartreuse. East Prospect of Giants Causeway. Castle of Segovia.

 Lake of Killarney from Kenmre Park

 Each suscrber will thus be furnished yearly with I3 superior Copperpate Engravings the price of which, if purchased singy, would be more than double the annual cost of the entire work.

 W. THE ToILET.-In addition to the usual literary matter contained in similar publications, the Propre tor has completed arrangement by which he will be enabled to furnish orrect descriptions of the prevail ing fashions, both Foreign and domestic illustrated with elegant engravngs, besides the regular series. once in each quarter; places of fashionable resorts sketches ofl manners, Sc. Lc. at the earliest DOS. sble period, and from the most authentic sources.

 V. Editors Department; Notices of passing events: The Drama; New Publications; Criticisms, Reviews, &c. &C.

 The Question Settled.-A vote was recently taken on board steamboat, on her passage from New-Or- leans tO Louisville, and the result was 99 for Adams and 96 for Jackson.
